column1: Analysis - Finance - Manual Refunds FX is sending GL's prior to FX rate job, resulting in different rates used and different document dates for GL vs. SETTLEFX
column30:
Detailed description of the defect: This defect was originally identified in DF-49 on 11/18/25 but was not prioritized due to the low volume. DF-55 was subsequently opened for what seemed to be a different issue, but using the details from DF-55, I discovered that both defects are symptoms of the same problem. 

Instead, it appears that we have an issue that we had seen in Production 21B back in early 2024 specifically related to manual refunds that were sending GL documents upon transaction approval, prior to FX rate being applied to the transaction. This looks very similar to a 21B issue that was resolved via analysis done in SEAS-2613 back in April 2024.

The first "live" scenario we are running into in 24A includes:
Reservation = 43709395
Trans ID = 74224143
GL Trans ID = 395510246

Seaware Timestamps:
Transaction Create = 11/20/2025 2:46:45 PM
Transaction Approval = 11/21/2025 7:07:11 PM
GL Timestamp = 11/21/2025 7:07:15 PM

Last 6 Latest Scuttle Rate Timestamps as of 11/26/25:
11/26/25, 11:56 AM        MICHAEL.LEO@DISNEY.COM
11/20/25, 3:18 PM        JENNIFER.L.POORVIN@DISNEY.COM
11/20/25, 12:33 PM        DOMINIC.FOTI@DISNEY.COM
11/18/25, 2:19 PM        DOMINIC.FOTI@DISNEY.COM
11/18/25, 2:15 PM        DOMINIC.FOTI@DISNEY.COM
11/18/25, 1:58 PM        Dominic.Foti@disney.com

The second most recent FX Rate job was run on 11/20. Transaction 74224143 was approved and the GL was created at 7pm 11/21, which was almost five days before the next Rate job run on 11/26. At this time, the GL should not have been created until the next rate job on 11/26, but CAP received a GL document on 11/21:

2025-11-21:SED:SETTLE-74224143: Settlement (NO TRANSLATION)
2025-11-21:SED:GL-395510246

It wasn't until the rate was run on 11/26 that we got the converted settlement:

2025-11-26:SED:SETTLEFX-74224143

We need to ensure that the GL for FX Manual Refunds do not send until the FX rate has been assigned to the transaction.


Specific steps to recreate issue: 
 - Expected results should be (how it should have worked): 2025-11-21:SED:GL-395510246 send upon transaction approval when it should have held until the rate was assigned to the transaction.
 - Actual results (what actually occurred): 2025-11-21:SED:GL-395510246 should have sent and been dated 11/26 when the rate was assigned.

column30:
*Feature: Commission Tier Reassignment*
 
  *# Positive Scenarios*
  Scenario: Increase commission tier level
    Given an agency exists in Seaware
    And the agency has a current tier level lower than the new tier level
    When the process runs for tier reassignment
    Then the current record should have sail_date_to updated to the new sail date
    And a new record should be inserted with the new tier level and effective dates
 
  Scenario: Decrease commission tier level
    Given an agency exists in Seaware
    And the agency has a current tier level higher than the new tier level
    When the process runs for tier reassignment
    Then the current record should have eff_date_to updated to the tier down date
    And a new record should be inserted with the new tier level and effective dates
 
  Scenario: Insert tier record for agency with no existing tier
    Given an agency exists in Seaware
    And the agency has no record in Seaware.Agency_Commission_Tier
    When the process runs for tier reassignment
    Then a new record should be inserted with the new tier level and default effective dates
 
  Scenario: Validate sail date format for tier reassignment
    Given the user provides a sail date in 'MM/DD/YYYY' format
    When the process runs
    Then the date should be accepted and applied to the new record
 
  *# Negative Scenarios*
  Scenario: Skip tier reassignment for agency not in Seaware
    Given an agency adjustment exists in Busobj.Agency_Adjust_Commission_Tier
    And the agency does not exist in Seaware.Agency
    When the process runs for tier reassignment
    Then the agency should be skipped
    And a message should be logged indicating the agency is missing
 
  Scenario: Reject invalid sail date format
    Given the user provides a sail date in 'YYYY/MM/DD' format
    When the process runs
    Then the process should fail validation
    And an error message should indicate the correct format is 'MM/DD/YYYY'
 
  Scenario: Reject sail date earlier than effective date
    Given the user provides a sail date that is before the effective date
    When the process runs
    Then the process should fail validation
    And an error message should indicate that sail date must be after effective date

column1: Analysis - Finance | 11/18 FX Transaction sent twice to CAP
column30:
Detailed description of the defect: We received a duplication of the FX transaction 74212690, resulting in a quarantine in CAP Shadow. Screenshots are attached showing that both the SETTLE and the SETTLEFX were received after the successful SETTLEFX transaction. Need to confirm why exactly this record sent twice.

Here are the specifics of what I can see for Transaction 7412690:
11/18 1:45 PM: Refund was created
11/18 2:16 PM: Refund was Approved
11/19 7:34:55 PM: SETTLEFX-74212690 (converted rate) received in CAP Shadow
11/19 7:35:02 PM: (7 seconds later) SETTLE-74212690 (non converted) received in CAP Shadow, quarantined as a duplicate
11/19 8:11:11 PM: SETTLEFX-74212690 (converted rate) received in CAP Shadow, quarantined as a duplicate

I need to understand how the file duplicated like this. We did have an issue where Settlements were held up due to a logjam in Seaware, but I can't prove whether or not this was impacted by that or not.

My first thought was when the logjam was fixed in Seaware Latest, perhaps the Settle FX sent out of order. While this may be the case, the same did NOT happen for similarly timed transaction 74212691, which happened less than a minute later and worked as expected.

Specific steps to recreate issue: 
 - Expected results should be (how it should have worked): should have only sent one time.
 - Actual results (what actually occurred): sent twice.

column1: Analysis - Finance | Refunds for G&A transactions originally made on Main are triggering GDS Client ID in APP.
column30:
Detailed description of the defect: I have noticed than any refund of a G&A that was made originally on Seaware Main is showing an abnormality in the Client ID being triggered. I have attached a production example for Reservation 43358444 (Prod Res 43358444 G&A Payment/Refund files) compared to Latest Reservation 43708432 (Latest Res 43708432 G&A Payment/Refund files).

In summary:

Prod G&A Reservation 43358444:
Payment Client ID = DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) - Seaware - CNP (Call Center)
Refund Client ID = DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) - Seaware - Refund by RRN

Latest G&A Reservation 43708432:
Payment Client ID = DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) - Seaware - CNP (Call Center)
Refund Client ID = DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) Seaware - CNP (GDS)

This only appears to specifically be impacting the refunds of G&A transactions. Standard reservation refunds made through Main, as well as G&A refunds made via digital/web, seem to be working as expected.

Specific steps to recreate issue: Based on the volume it seems that this could be recreated by paying for a Gift/Amenity on Seaware Main and refunding that payment.

 - Expected results should be (how it should have worked): The Client ID used in Latest for the Refund of 43708432 should be one of a) DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) - Seaware - Refund by RRN or b) DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) - Seaware - CNP (Call Center). Need to understand why the GDS Client ID was triggered since it should not have had any part of the transaction. 
 - Actual results (what actually occurred):  DSE Cruise Reservations - DCL (USD) Seaware - CNP (GDS) is the Client ID used for Seaware Main G&A Refunds

column279:
01/Dec/2025 5:56 PM;sara.g.abdulla.-nd@disney.com;Analysis on Existing SeaCap flow for populating Journal.

While building Cap request data, for the General Ledger,  the method 'PopulateCapJournalByGroupId' finds the Voyage by passing Group's Sail date detail. 

Group detail fetched using below package:

Package: BUSOBJ.GROUP_PKG
Stored Proc: GetByGroupId
View:  BUSOBJ.GROUP_V

Voyage extracted from VoyageCache by passing Group's ShipCode, SailDateFrom and SailDateTo. 

LookupData for Voyage loaded by below package. 

Package: SAIL_HEADER_PKG
Stored Proc: GetBySailDateRange
View: BUSOBJ.SAIL_HEADER_V
Table: SEAWARE.SAIL_HEADER
Field: SAIL_CODE

So in the view 'SAIL_HEADER_V', Voyage data extracted based on IS_ACTIVE = 'Y'.

The GroupId 30008402 is active. But the Voyage returned by passing group's shipcode and sail detail is inactive.

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 


That's the reason we see this error: Couldn't find Voyage for Group Id 30008402
;;;

h2. Objective

Re-architect the CAP services from a monolithic .NET application into scalable, testable microservices, prioritized by business-critical needs (e.g., new ships, PCEC, and financial reconciliation).
h3. Executive Summary

When a voyage is marked complete in Seaware, all reconciled transactions must be sent to CAP and then to SAP for revenue recognition. This microservice handles the detection, processing, and submission of those transactions.
h3. Common Features Across All Components
 * Microservice scaffolding in Java/TypeScript
 * Event-driven architecture
 * Retry logic and error handling
 * Logging and observability (Splunk dashboards, etc.)
 * Unit and integration test coverage
 * CAP API integration
 * SAP journal formatting and submission

----
h2. Voyage Termination Microservice – High-Level Workflow
h3. 1. *Detection & Triggering*
 * {*}Input{*}: Seaware voyage marked as terminated (manually or via scheduled job).
 * {*}Action{*}: Microservice queries Seaware for voyages eligible for termination.
 * {*}Logic{*}: Compares against internal logs to determine if the voyage has already been processed.
 * {*}Output{*}: If unprocessed, a “Voyage Termination Started” event is logged.

h3. 2. *Event Logging & Progress Tracking*
 * {*}Start Event{*}: Logs the initiation of the voyage termination process.
 * {*}Progress Events{*}: Tracks how many transactions have been processed (e.g., 100 of 100,000).
 * {*}End Event{*}: Logs completion once all transactions are successfully sent to CAP and acknowledged.

h3. 3. *Transaction Fetching & Data Enrichment*
 * {*}Input{*}: Voyage ID from Seaware.
 * {*}Action{*}: Fetches all financial transactions tied to the voyage.
 * {*}Enrichment{*}: Adds required metadata (e.g., guest info, voyage ID, GL codes) from Seaware and other sources.
 * {*}Validation{*}: Ensures all required fields for CAP/SAP submission are present.

h3. 4. *Data Transformation & Journal Construction*
 * {*}Action{*}: Transforms enriched transactions into CAP-compliant journal entries.
 * {*}Structure{*}: Builds SAP batch headers and GL journal lines.
 * {*}Output{*}: Ready-to-send payloads for CAP.

h3. 5. *CAP Submission*
 * {*}Action{*}: Sends journal entries to CAP via API.
 * {*}Response Handling{*}:
 ** Success: Logs CAP response and marks transaction as complete.
 ** Failure: Logs error and queues for retry.

h3. 6. *Retry & Error Handling*
 * {*}Retry Logic{*}: Implements exponential backoff for transient failures.
 * {*}Error Logging{*}: Captures and stores failed transactions for manual review or automated retry.

h3. 7. *Observability & Admin Tools*
 * {*}Monitoring{*}: Real-time dashboards (e.g., Splunk) for VT progress and health.
 * *Admin UI* (optional): Internal tool to view recent VT events, statuses, and logs.

h3. 8. *Finalization*
 * {*}Accounting Schema Update{*}: Updates internal database with CAP response and marks voyage as processed.
 * {*}Seaware Sync{*}: Optionally updates Seaware to reflect completion (if needed).

column1: Transition Triton Applications from SOLO to Okta-backed MyID platform using the self-service ACME tool
column30:
The PingFederate MyID platform is on a deprecation path. All SEAS applications that use this platform via SOLO must migrate to the Okta MyID platform using the Application Configuration Management Engine (ACME) self-service tool. For this effort, the Crush and Triton studios will migrate individual applications owned by each, and will work with the Triton studio to validate certificates and links with SE. Each studio will have an Epic linked to this Feature.

h2. Key dates

* April 8th, 2025: No new SOLO integrations.
* September 25th, 2025: SOLO enters read-only mode.
* October 3, 2026: Full deprecation of SOLO.

Studios must be migrated by 3 Oct 2026 (end of support), but the target date is 25 Sep 2025 (read only). Changes to records in SOLO have been infrequent, but once it is in read-only, we would not be able to make changes if the need arose.

h2. Reference

- SOLO: https://solo.myid.disney.com/
- ACME: https://acme.myid.disney.com
- ACME transition homepage (IAM Transformation Program Confluence): https://confluence.disney.com/x/VaIOX
- ACME and Okta (IAM Confluence): https://confluence.disney.com/x/vMazYQ
- ACME Notice of Decision (NOD) (Confluence): https://confluence.disney.com/x/-ppUYQ
- Okta MyID Platform Onboarding Office Hours: https://confluence.disney.com/x/8rt-Yw

h2. Contact / Questions

- For technical support, submit a support request to the assignment group "Sec-Global-Okta Platform Onboarding".
- For general questions regarding IAM Transformation, reach out to the IAM Transformation Team at IAM.Transformation@Disney.com

h3. *Purpose of this Epic*

To organize the stories for the work to refactor the 1099 reporting process.
h3. *Purpose of the 1099 Report*

The 1099 report is used to provide 1099 tax documents to travel agencies and the government. It details how much each agency has earned over the year. The report is crucial for ensuring compliance with IRS requirements, including accurate revenue reporting and validation of Tax Identification Numbers (TINs) for non-corporate, US-based agencies that earned more than $600 annually
h3. *Process Overview*

There are three parts to this process which are handled by two teams:
 # Agency Information Review
 ## This process is run every month and will generate a cumulative report of all commission for YTD which is reviewed by finance to ensure the agency information is accurate for all agencies according to the IRS website
 # Commission Value Review
 ## This process starts in October and uses the Cumulative report to validate and verify that the commissions reported match the commissions paid out to the Travel Agents.
 ## Near the end of December, Manual transactions are added to the report? ZGUFI - Transactions out of SAP that will be missing in Seaware. (This may change the eligibility of the TA if they move past the threshold.)
 # End of year processing and sending to the IRS
 ## This process starts on January first of every year and is completed in the second week of January after making any necessary adjustments to the report when the Fin Ops team sends the report to the Accounts Payable team to be sent out to the IRS 

{*}Data Sources{*}:
 * Agency Audit
 ** Seaware
 ** SAP/DSMP
 ** IRS Website
 ** Zendesk

 * Value Audit
 ** Seaware
 ** SAP
 ** Business Objects Reporting

*Reports:*
 * IRS1099_DCL - The Final File sent the IRS
 * Agency Audit Reports:  These should be chapters in micro strategy.
 ** DuplicatePrimaryAddress.csv
 ** DuplicateSecondaryAddress.csv
 ** IRS1099_Duplicate_TINs.csv
 ** IRS1099MissingTins.csv
 * Value Audit Report: This report shows all the detailed transactions which make up the commission payments
 ** Agency1099Detail.csv

 

*Population:* 
    i.      Non-Corporation, US based Agencies
    ii.      Earned more than $600 a year
    iii.      Adds total commission, gross up and tour credit transactions for a full total 
    iv.      Timeframe: 12/30 the year prior to the end of that current month. Example: 12/30/2023 – 12/31/2024.  

 

*Stakeholders:*
The process involves Financial Operations, with Jennifer Pinkasavage handling agency details and Kyann Pierce managing commission values. DCL IT provides monthly reports

h2. Objective

Re-architect the CAP services from a monolithic .NET application into scalable, testable microservices, prioritized by business-critical needs (e.g., new ships, PCEC, and financial reconciliation).
h3. Executive Summary

When a voyage is marked complete in Seaware, all reconciled transactions must be sent to CAP and then to SAP for revenue recognition. This microservice handles the detection, processing, and submission of those transactions.
h3. Common Features Across All Components
 * Microservice scaffolding in Java/TypeScript
 * Event-driven architecture
 * Retry logic and error handling
 * Logging and observability (Splunk dashboards, etc.)
 * Unit and integration test coverage
 * CAP API integration
 * SAP journal formatting and submission

----
h2. Voyage Termination Microservice – High-Level Workflow
h3. 1. *Detection & Triggering*
 * {*}Input{*}: Seaware voyage marked as terminated (manually or via scheduled job).
 * {*}Action{*}: Microservice queries Seaware for voyages eligible for termination.
 * {*}Logic{*}: Compares against internal logs to determine if the voyage has already been processed.
 * {*}Output{*}: If unprocessed, a “Voyage Termination Started” event is logged.

h3. 2. *Event Logging & Progress Tracking*
 * {*}Start Event{*}: Logs the initiation of the voyage termination process.
 * {*}Progress Events{*}: Tracks how many transactions have been processed (e.g., 100 of 100,000).
 * {*}End Event{*}: Logs completion once all transactions are successfully sent to CAP and acknowledged.

h3. 3. *Transaction Fetching & Data Enrichment*
 * {*}Input{*}: Voyage ID from Seaware.
 * {*}Action{*}: Fetches all financial transactions tied to the voyage.
 * {*}Enrichment{*}: Adds required metadata (e.g., guest info, voyage ID, GL codes) from Seaware and other sources.
 * {*}Validation{*}: Ensures all required fields for CAP/SAP submission are present.

h3. 4. *Data Transformation & Journal Construction*
 * {*}Action{*}: Transforms enriched transactions into CAP-compliant journal entries.
 * {*}Structure{*}: Builds SAP batch headers and GL journal lines.
 * {*}Output{*}: Ready-to-send payloads for CAP.

h3. 5. *CAP Submission*
 * {*}Action{*}: Sends journal entries to CAP via API.
 * {*}Response Handling{*}:
 ** Success: Logs CAP response and marks transaction as complete.
 ** Failure: Logs error and queues for retry.

h3. 6. *Retry & Error Handling*
 * {*}Retry Logic{*}: Implements exponential backoff for transient failures.
 * {*}Error Logging{*}: Captures and stores failed transactions for manual review or automated retry.

h3. 7. *Observability & Admin Tools*
 * {*}Monitoring{*}: Real-time dashboards (e.g., Splunk) for VT progress and health.
 * *Admin UI* (optional): Internal tool to view recent VT events, statuses, and logs.

h3. 8. *Finalization*
 * {*}Accounting Schema Update{*}: Updates internal database with CAP response and marks voyage as processed.
 * {*}Seaware Sync{*}: Optionally updates Seaware to reflect completion (if needed).
